subject: Re: [junit] question about Assert.assertEquals
msgSnippet: ... No problem. A superclass comparing itself to a subclass can never work unless the subclass has nothing new to add to the superclass. I think we re in
messageBody:
>So said Kevin Klinemeier on 2003-05-07 --------------------
>I meant to also include this bit in my reply:
>
>> >So, in summary, I'm saying that if you subclass an equals for
>> anything
>> >but Object, you're going to break it. Be sure that you break it in
>> a
>> >way that you expect. Does that make sense?
>>
>> No, because it isn't true.
>
>You're right, I left out the 'adding an aspect' bit, and was assuming
>we were talking about superclasses that attempt to compare themselves
>to subclasses. Sorry about that.

No problem. A superclass comparing itself to a subclass can never work unless the subclass has nothing new to add to the superclass. I think we're in complete agreement. :)


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
